questions.question: Which of these choices best describes the thermal energy of a substance?

choices.answer: all of the kin energy of all of the particlesof a material
average kin energy of the particles that make up asubstance
total kin and pot energies of theparticles of a substance

questions.question: How can you increase the thermal energy of a bottle of water?

choices.answer: pour the water into a larger bottle
increase the temperature of the water.
place the bottle of water in the refrigerator.
divide the water between two identical containers

questions.question: Two beakers of difference sizes have the same temperature water. Which has more thermal energy?

choices.answer: they have the same thermal energy

questions.question: What is the Definition of heat?

choices.answer: total thermal energy of an object or substance
change of temp of a substance in degreesCelsius
energy transferred between things at diff temps.
avg kinetic energy of the particles that make up asubstance

questions.question: How is temperature related to heat?

choices.answer: Temperature is a measure of the heat of an object
Heat causes a change in the temperature of an object
Raising the temp causes the heat of an objectto increase
Temp and heat are 2 different ways to measurethe same thing

questions.question: How does heat affect the therm energy of an objectthat is colder than the air that surrounds it

choices.answer: Heat lowers the therm energy of an object asenergy goes out
Heat makes TE to go up as E moves from air to the object.
Heat has no effect on TE, but it adds to the PE of an object
Heat is not related to TE, so it can't change TE of anything

questions.question: As energy in the form of heat is added to an ice cube,it begins to melt. What causes melting?

choices.answer: Heat causes the molecules to expandand forces them apart.
Heat takes TE from the ice andcauses it to become liquid.
Extra energy causes the bonds between H & O in ice to break.
The transfer of TE to ice causesits molecules to move faster

choices.answer: feeling warmth when you sit in a sunny place
feeling warm air while standing near a fan from a AC system
